values.title: implement DARTLink::Set/GetKinematic
Tutorials/1.9/custom_messages issue

content.raw:
When I was creating custom messages for my project I faced with an issue in this tutorial http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.9/custom_messages. I caught a bug becase of this lines in CMakeLists.txt.


```
#!c++



set (msgs
  collision_map_request.proto
  ${PROTOBUF_IMPORT_DIRS}/vector2d.proto
  ${PROTOBUF_IMPORT_DIRS}/header.proto
  ${PROTOBUF_IMPORT_DIRS}/time.proto
)
PROTOBUF_GENERATE_CPP(PROTO_SRCS PROTO_HDRS ${msgs})
add_library(collision_map_creator_msgs SHARED ${PROTO_SRCS})
target_link_libraries(collision_map_creator_msgs ${PROTOBUF_LIBRARY})
```
After building my project with this message and executing it I've got such an error: 



```
#!

[libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/descriptor_database.cc:57] File already exists in database: time.proto
[libprotobuf FATAL google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:954] CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size): 
libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type google::protobuf::FatalException: CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size): 
```
Fixed this by adding ${GAZEBO_LIBRARIES} to target_link_libraries for collision_map_creator_msgs and switching from ${PROTO_SRCS} to collision_map_request.pb.cc
content.html:
When I was creating custom messages for my project I faced with an issue in this tutorial http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.9/custom_messages. I caught a bug becase of this lines in CMakeLists.txt.

set (msgs
  collision_map_request.proto
  ${PROTOBUF_IMPORT_DIRS}/vector2d.proto
  ${PROTOBUF_IMPORT_DIRS}/header.proto
  ${PROTOBUF_IMPORT_DIRS}/time.proto
)
PROTOBUF_GENERATE_CPP(PROTO_SRCS PROTO_HDRS ${msgs})
add_library(collision_map_creator_msgs SHARED ${PROTO_SRCS})
target_link_libraries(collision_map_creator_msgs ${PROTOBUF_LIBRARY})

After building my project with this message and executing it I've got such an error: 

[libprotobuf ERROR google/protobuf/descriptor_database.cc:57] File already exists in database: time.proto
[libprotobuf FATAL google/protobuf/descriptor.cc:954] CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size): 
libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type google::protobuf::FatalException: CHECK failed: generated_database_->Add(encoded_file_descriptor, size):

Fixed this by adding ${GAZEBO_LIBRARIES} to target_link_libraries for collision_map_creator_msgs and switching from ${PROTO_SRCS} to collision_map_request.pb.cc

values.title: gz model spawn/delete

content.raw:
gz model spawn let me create several models with the same name. Both are visualized but only one of them is shown in the left panel under Models. I was able to generate an inconsistency by spawning boxes with same name and removing them by selecting + del button. They were removed but the panel still show the model name.

The command does not provide any kind of feedback. Probably, by design, there is not return after sending the action. The major problem is that under error circumstances, like asking for action on an non existing model it is returning nothing also. An use case would be to have a typo in a model name and the user don't know what's happening.

values.title: Thread pitch definition is unclear (convert gazebo from rad/m to m/revolution)

content.raw:
The unit of thread pitch for screw joint is not specified on [ScrewJoint.hh](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/6d9cc8763baf1697f4f93b27311fb722997ec10e/gazebo/physics/ScrewJoint.hh?at=default#cl-122) nor [sdf](http://gazebosim.org/sdf/dev.html#thread_pitch371).

In [screw_joint.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1007/implement-screw-joint-in-simbody-and-clean/diff#Ltest/integration/joint_screw.ccT116), the thread pitch seems to be defined as a proceeding distance per one radian. According to [wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screw_thread), thread pitch is the distance along the screw's axis that is covered by one complete rotation of the screw (360°) for single-start threadforms. DART is also following the definition of wikipedia's.

It would be nice to document the unit of thread pitch on ScrewJoint.hh and sdf to make it clear.
content.html:
The unit of thread pitch for screw joint is not specified on ScrewJoint.hh nor sdf.

In screw_joint.cc, the thread pitch seems to be defined as a proceeding distance per one radian. According to wikipedia, thread pitch is the distance along the screw's axis that is covered by one complete rotation of the screw (360°) for single-start threadforms. DART is also following the definition of wikipedia's.

It would be nice to document the unit of thread pitch on ScrewJoint.hh and sdf to make it clear.

values.title: Sensor destructor are never called after Model removal

content.raw:
Apparently (tried on current default with some prints) Joint (and Link) destructors methods are never called when the corresponding Model is removed from the simulation. 

Is this the intended behaviour?

We became aware of this issue because we have some sensor plugins that opened some connections, and we had crashes when exiting. 

Apparently the sensor plugins that are child of Link elements close correctly because they are removed in the Link::Fini() method [1] that is properly called, while the sensor plugins that are child of Joint elements don't close correctly because they should be removed in Joint destructor [2], that is never called.

If this is the intended behaviour, it is then difficult to handle connection in joint-sensor plugins, because there is no place in which to close the opened connections. 


[1] : #!/osrf/gazebo/src/399a916b9ae4d64b1c570209a9b7eb889466d795/gazebo/physics/Link.cc?at=default#cl-256

[2] : #!/osrf/gazebo/src/399a916b9ae4d64b1c570209a9b7eb889466d795/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc?at=default#cl-81

values.title: Bullet Universal Joint will not work near/outside (-π/2, +π/2)

content.raw:
Universal joint goes unstable and behaves incorrectly when the joint angle approaches +/-π/2.

One potential fix is to apply a similar patch to use cumulative angle in ODE.
content.html:
Universal joint goes unstable and behaves incorrectly when the joint angle approaches +/-π/2.

One potential fix is to apply a similar patch to use cumulative angle in ODE.

values.title: Improve usability for --physics option

content.raw:
We could improve the way of handling the -e or --physics option in the gzserver.

When passed an invalid value gazebo is starting with given any hint to the user about the fallback option taken or the error.

```
gazebo -e non_valid
```

For extra points, try to detect if the support for one of the physics engines is not implemented and don't allow the user to run the -e option with the unsupported physics engine.
content.html:
We could improve the way of handling the -e or --physics option in the gzserver.

When passed an invalid value gazebo is starting with given any hint to the user about the fallback option taken or the error.

gazebo -e non_valid

For extra points, try to detect if the support for one of the physics engines is not implemented and don't allow the user to run the -e option with the unsupported physics engine.

values.title: Display which physics engine is being used by gazebo

content.raw:
Sometimes is hard to know which physics engine is being used by gazebo, specially sensible to the effect described in issue #1120, which by a lack of support or a type, someone could end up thinking that is used a physics engine but really fall into default as consequence of an error.

It would help if gzclient could display somehow which physics engine is in use.

It could also be a good idea to display it through the command line via gz tool.

values.title: gazebo::rendering::Camera::IsVisible()  is Broken

content.raw:
It appears gazebo::rendering::Camera::IsVisible() is broken for models and joints. I've attached images demonstrating 3 test cases and the code to create them, and the Camera box is selected with the triad in all 3 cases:

1.  Camera pointing at 2 visible boxes, one with a joint. 
      - The sphere attached to the joint and the "visible" tagged model component of the sdf are both not marked visible when they should be.
2. Camera pointing at the original start location of the boxes, but the boxes were moved behind the camera box.
      - Both of the boxes are marked visible, when they are not actually visible.
3. Camera rotated ~100 degrees away from the client camera
      - Everything is correctly marked as not visible

This seems to mean that the isVisible() function does not update correctly when a human moves models using gzclient. However, I have not tested moving the correctness of moving models in an animation. Perhaps the scene graph isn't updating?

The second critical issue here is that isVisible() does not work at all for an entire "link", "visible" components of links, or "collision" components of links. 

In my use case it is important that individual visible models each be testable with isVisible, because my camera is close to an extremely large object, and so cannot see the complete entity, and I need to verify what links are actually visible in ground truth. Perhaps there is an alternative workaround?

I am on commit 9e1054fd54b4, with the parent de20d7921de6 on the default branch. 

http://gazebosim.org/api/dev/classgazebo_1_1rendering_1_1Camera.html#af0044dea16bbc2733777ed1ca46ba21e
content.html:
It appears gazebo::rendering::Camera::IsVisible() is broken for models and joints. I've attached images demonstrating 3 test cases and the code to create them, and the Camera box is selected with the triad in all 3 cases:

  1. Camera pointing at 2 visible boxes, one with a joint.
    • The sphere attached to the joint and the "visible" tagged model component of the sdf are both not marked visible when they should be.
  2. Camera pointing at the original start location of the boxes, but the boxes were moved behind the camera box.
    • Both of the boxes are marked visible, when they are not actually visible.
  3. Camera rotated ~100 degrees away from the client camera
    • Everything is correctly marked as not visible

This seems to mean that the isVisible() function does not update correctly when a human moves models using gzclient. However, I have not tested moving the correctness of moving models in an animation. Perhaps the scene graph isn't updating?

The second critical issue here is that isVisible() does not work at all for an entire "link", "visible" components of links, or "collision" components of links.

In my use case it is important that individual visible models each be testable with isVisible, because my camera is close to an extremely large object, and so cannot see the complete entity, and I need to verify what links are actually visible in ground truth. Perhaps there is an alternative workaround?

I am on commit 9e1054fd54b4, with the parent de20d7921de6 on the default branch.

values.title: Create "static" joint definition in SDF

content.raw:
It looks like there is a "fixed" joint in UDRF, and we should create an equivalent in SDF.

UDRF example:
http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.9/Using_A_URDF_In_Gazebo

A gazebo answers question addressed the issue but the referenced model has been moved to the deprecated folder:
http://answers.gazebosim.org/question/1321/a-correct-way-to-implement-fixed-joint/

The current workaround is to set the joint to type "revolute" and set the low and high stop parameters to 0.

The format could be as follows:


```
#!xml

<joint name="joint1" type="static">
        <parent>boxlink</parent>
        <child>point1</child>
 </joint>
```

values.title: Expand Documentation Explaining Design and Usage of Gazebo

content.raw:
An improvement that would be extremely helpful and smooth out the process for new users would be more documentation of the overall design concepts and usage of gazebo. The overall design of gazebo is quite good, which means a lot can be accomplished by improving how that design is communicated to users.

**Edit:** I've found the [User Guide](http://gazebosim.org/user_guide/index.html), but it is out of date (1.9) and should be linked to in the "Get your feet wet" section of the [Getting Started](http://gazebosim.org/#getstarted) section of the gazebosim.org front page.

For example, while there was a genuine bug in issue #1127, one source of confusion was figuring out how visual strings are modified. 

**Specific points of confusion:**

1. How to access SDF elements in C++
      * I had to look through the code to discover that simply using link names would fail
2. Interaction of model class names, registered names, shared library filenames and what the constraints of those elements are.

**What could be added:**

1. Dictionary - explain specific terms, and in what contexts they can be used
      * **visual** example:
           * Applies to modules: SDF, Rendering, Physics
           * A visual element can be identified by either a unique string and/or integer identifier
           * The name string of a visual element in the SDF file is not the same name as the visual identifer string in C++ code. Instead, the C++ visual identifier string is composed from the scope of the visual identifier and its parents element. For example if you have a model "modelname" that contains a link "linkname" which contains a visual "visualname", the model unique identifier is "modelname" the link unique identifier is "modelname::linkname", and the visual unique identifier is "modelname::linkname::visualname".
           * The visual element interacts with the rendering scene and can be used to extract information about the scene and ground truth data about how sensors are interacting with the simulation.
            * Other related functions and components you may want to see include: class1 class2, function1, ...
     * Additional terms that need to be identified and have their interaction with other components explained:
         * Scene, Model, link, plugin, script, event, collision, actor, model, factory, node (including both transport and scene graph contexts),  etc...

2. Explanation of API functions and cross referencing could make it easier to understand and use components. Some of the API documentation is a restatement of the function names at the moment.
      * Taking the "visual" example above, I did search the wiki for "visual" and was brought to this page: http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Interfaces . This would likely be a good spot to put some additional details explaining what these elements are. 
      * Here is an example demonstrating how the function description is a restatement of the function name itself: http://gazebosim.org/api/dev/classgazebo_1_1rendering_1_1Scene.html#a8dc996b50f1ed9585f845738b94fdfcc
         * Ideally the keyword **visual** could be turned into a link or use one of the inline doxygen reference definitions to the definition of what exactly constitutes a visual string. This would mean less writing but still allow people to find the information quickly. Also, a short description of why you would want to use it would be helpful. 
      * A good example library documentation is the boost.geometry library.
         * Overall library: boost.org/libs/geometry
         * Example function: http://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_55_0/libs/geometry/doc/html/geometry/reference/access/get/get_1.html

3. Clear and easy ways to debug and diagnose and resolve problems with loading plugins, including printing the set of paths that were searched and warning of duplicate library names on the path.
4. Error messages explaining or guessing what may be wrong with an SDF file, plus instructions on how to fix it, or where to find said instructions.

values.title: Simplify the process of using gazebo as a library even more

content.raw:
per pull request #929, having the main version take `char**` and `int` parameters makes it a bit more difficult to use if you already process the command line arguments in a different way. Could the `setup*` functions also be overloaded as follows? 

```
#!c++

setupServer(std::vector<std::string>& args)
```

It would also be awesome if the expectations for the parameters for those functions were documented in the meantime. That is, what are the strings expected to contain?

I believe the answer is a list of paths to plugins to load, but I'm not 100% certain.

values.title: 3D meshes: vertices not shared among faces, resulting in large files

content.raw:
For example, `cordless_drill.dae` has:
`565 vertices` and `1126 faces`.

But once loaded into gzserver, it has:
`3378 vertices` and `1126 faces`.

Because once loaded, each vertex and each edge belong to only one face. This means there are several overlapped vertices and the faces are not connected.

It would be interesting to arrange the mesh so that these vertices can be shared among faces like in the original file, resulting in a lighter mesh.
content.html:
For example, cordless_drill.dae has: 565 vertices and 1126 faces.

But once loaded into gzserver, it has: 3378 vertices and 1126 faces.

Because once loaded, each vertex and each edge belong to only one face. This means there are several overlapped vertices and the faces are not connected.

It would be interesting to arrange the mesh so that these vertices can be shared among faces like in the original file, resulting in a lighter mesh.

values.title: Possible memory leak

content.raw: I left my system running the animation demo example in pull request #1023 overnight and my computer ran out of memory. While I'm not 100% certain, I wanted to report the information in case you find it worth investigating. I do not believe the issue is related to the demo code itself, but possibly some of the underlying gazebo libraries.

values.title: Custom protobuf example that imports gazebo protobufs

content.raw:
It would be helpful if the protocol buffer example were also available in the example code folder. This could also avoid future problems should anything change in the setup.

Here is the existing example that imports gazebo protobufs:
http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.9/custom_messages

It would also be great if the [customized protobuf message components](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d6bfa5238c7c0cb3963716df16475b97f1f0051b/gazebo/msgs/CMakeLists.txt?at=default) could be pulled out of the CMakeLists.txt function and made available when installed, perhaps via the gazeboConfig.cmake file, or by a separate file in the shared folder.
content.html:
It would be helpful if the protocol buffer example were also available in the example code folder. This could also avoid future problems should anything change in the setup.

Here is the existing example that imports gazebo protobufs: http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.9/custom_messages

It would also be great if the customized protobuf message components could be pulled out of the CMakeLists.txt function and made available when installed, perhaps via the gazeboConfig.cmake file, or by a separate file in the shared folder.

values.title: gazebo3-prerelease debian package breaks CMake's find_package(gazebo)

content.raw:
I don't know if gazebo3-prerelease is a debian package intended for the public or just for internal testing, in the latter case just close this issue. 

Apparently, the gazebo3-prerelease debian package breaks the CMake command find_package(gazebo REQUIRED), that is working when using gazebo-current package (tested in Ubuntu 12.04 & 13.10 ).

find_package(gazebo REQUIRED) fails with this message:
```
CMake Error at /usr/share/gazebo/cmake/gazebo-config.cmake:22 (message):

Library 'gazebo' in package GAZEBO is not installed properly
```

Apparently this does not happen when installing gazebo from hg repository. 


For a CMake log of the failing configuration with gazebo3-prerelase compared with the successful configuration with gazebo-current, you can check this travis builds:

Failing with gazebo3-prerelease : https://travis-ci.org/robotology/gazebo_yarp_plugins/jobs/22097658

Success with gazebo-current : https://travis-ci.org/robotology/gazebo_yarp_plugins/jobs/22096377

values.title: make doc is failing in Saucy/Trusty (doxygen problem)

content.raw:
[During the saucy generation for gazebo3](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo3-debbuilder/32/consoleFull) doxygen ends with an error. This is not happening in previous Ubuntu versions.

Looking at our [cmake definition](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d6bfa5238c7c0cb3963716df16475b97f1f0051b/doc/CMakeLists.txt?at=default) to run```make doc``` it is failing when running:

``` COMMAND make -C ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/doxygen/latex```

The makefile inside build/doxygen/latex is:

```
#!makefile
refman.pdf: clean refman.tex
	pdflatex refman
	makeindex refman.idx
	pdflatex refman
	latex_count=5 ; \
	while egrep -s 'Rerun (LaTeX|to get cross-references right)' refman.log && [ $$latex_count -gt 0 ] ;\
	    do \
	      echo "Rerunning latex...." ;\
	      pdflatex refman ;\
	      latex_count=`expr $$latex_count - 1` ;\
	    done
	makeindex refman.idx
	pdflatex refman
```
content.html:
During the saucy generation for gazebo3 doxygen ends with an error. This is not happening in previous Ubuntu versions.

Looking at our cmake definition to runmake doc it is failing when running:

COMMAND make -C ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/doxygen/latex

The makefile inside build/doxygen/latex is:

refman.pdf: clean refman.tex
    pdflatex refman
    makeindex refman.idx
    pdflatex refman
    latex_count=5 ; \
    while egrep -s 'Rerun (LaTeX|to get cross-references right)' refman.log && [ $$latex_count -gt 0 ] ;\
        do \
          echo "Rerunning latex...." ;\
          pdflatex refman ;\
          latex_count=`expr $$latex_count - 1` ;\
        done
    makeindex refman.idx
    pdflatex refman

values.title: Potential for smart pointer reference loops in physics::Base

content.raw: The `physics::Base` class stores the objects in the world as a hierarchy (Model, Link, Collision, Joint, etc.). Each objects stores a [vector of smart pointers to its children](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d6bfa5238c7c0cb3963716df16475b97f1f0051b/gazebo/physics/Base.hh?at=default#cl-308) as well as a [smart pointer to its parent](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d6bfa5238c7c0cb3963716df16475b97f1f0051b/gazebo/physics/Base.hh?at=default#cl-305). This has the potential to create [smart pointer reference loops](http://www.efnetcpp.org/wiki/Smart_pointer). We should consider changing the parent pointer to a weak shared pointer.
content.html: The physics::Base class stores the objects in the world as a hierarchy (Model, Link, Collision, Joint, etc.). Each objects stores a vector of smart pointers to its children as well as a smart pointer to its parent. This has the potential to create smart pointer reference loops. We should consider changing the parent pointer to a weak shared pointer.

values.title: custom main problems with time and loading plugins

content.raw:
If you take the [custom main](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d6bfa5238c7c0cb3963716df16475b97f1f0051b/examples/stand_alone/custom_main/custom_main.cc?at=default) example, and change `i < 2` to `i < 200000` the time and iterations in gzclient will not count correctly. 

Iterations will appear to run backwards from 100 down to 0 repeatedly, and real time will bounce around near 0, which is of course not the case. 

This image illustrates the problem, it was taken after running for about 1 minute:

![custom_main_bug.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/400736292-custom_main_bug.png)

It also seems that plugins may not load correctly from the world if I modify the custom main to load a more complicated .world file that includes a plug-in. 

I've also been able to verify this behavior with a significantly more complicated custom main that I have been implementing.

This is on OS X mavericks on the gazebo_3.0 branch, commit 9210f7bb0528.
content.html:
If you take the custom main example, and change i < 2 to i < 200000 the time and iterations in gzclient will not count correctly.

Iterations will appear to run backwards from 100 down to 0 repeatedly, and real time will bounce around near 0, which is of course not the case.

This image illustrates the problem, it was taken after running for about 1 minute:

It also seems that plugins may not load correctly from the world if I modify the custom main to load a more complicated .world file that includes a plug-in.

I've also been able to verify this behavior with a significantly more complicated custom main that I have been implementing.

This is on OS X mavericks on the gazebo_3.0 branch, commit 9210f7bb0528.

values.title: PhysicsEngine_TEST.cc missing simbody specialization

content.html:
simbody should be added to:

  if (_physicsEngine == "ode")
    type = msgs::Physics::ODE;
  else if (_physicsEngine == "bullet")
    type = msgs::Physics::BULLET;
  else if (_physicsEngine == "dart")
    type = msgs::Physics::DART;
  else
    type = msgs::Physics::ODE;

and have one of these for simbody

#ifdef HAVE_DART
TEST_F(PhysicsEngineTest, PhysicsEngineParamDART)
{
  PhysicsEngineParam("dart");
}
#endif  // HAVE_DART

values.title: Echo topic with custom messages doesn't work.

content.raw:
The command `gz topic -e <topic_path>` will not work if the message on the topic is a custom message.

There are two solutions:

1. Send the Protobuf debug string over the wire instead of the serialized message. 

2. Send a special [self-describing message](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/techniques#self-description).

Option 2 is the more elegant solution.
content.html:
The command gz topic -e <topic_path> will not work if the message on the topic is a custom message.

There are two solutions:

  1. Send the Protobuf debug string over the wire instead of the serialized message.

  2. Send a special self-describing message.

Option 2 is the more elegant solution.

values.title: GZ_ASSERT (hardcoded to 1 second) fails  for very high resolution sensors or very slow GPU
Model joint backlash

content.raw:
Backlash is an important nonlinear phenomenon in mechanical design and motor control. We should add it to gazebo.

We should be able to add backlash by adding an intermediate link and joint with position limits that correspond to the amount of backlash. This could be done manually; perhaps there is an easy way to add it if an sdformat tag is specified? It should also be specified when the backlash is before or after the measurement, since the location of a motor encoder has an impact on whether backlash is measurable.
content.html:
Backlash is an important nonlinear phenomenon in mechanical design and motor control. We should add it to gazebo.

We should be able to add backlash by adding an intermediate link and joint with position limits that correspond to the amount of backlash. This could be done manually; perhaps there is an easy way to add it if an sdformat tag is specified? It should also be specified when the backlash is before or after the measurement, since the location of a motor encoder has an impact on whether backlash is measurable.

values.title: truncate intermediate friction solutions by projecting it back down the an ellipse described by mu and mu2

content.raw: The idea is to project intermediate solution for friction directions from pyramid approximation to an ellipse (cone).  [Please see draft changes in this branch for example](#!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/friction_ellipse_projection..gazebo_3.0#diff).
content.html: The idea is to project intermediate solution for friction directions from pyramid approximation to an ellipse (cone). Please see draft changes in this branch for example.

values.title: Large models break the simulation

content.raw:
The attached version of animated_box.world creates a 7x7x7 box with some spheres on its surface. This model appears in the sky and jitters off into the distance. It is clearly triggering a severe bug, and I've been able to trigger it with numerous other models and configurations of similar size.

Enabling bullet physics reduces the severity of the problem, but it is still there. I've been able to make the attached spheres fly off when using bullet if I put the box into an animation that modifies pitch as well.
content.html:
The attached version of animated_box.world creates a 7x7x7 box with some spheres on its surface. This model appears in the sky and jitters off into the distance. It is clearly triggering a severe bug, and I've been able to trigger it with numerous other models and configurations of similar size.

Enabling bullet physics reduces the severity of the problem, but it is still there. I've been able to make the attached spheres fly off when using bullet if I put the box into an animation that modifies pitch as well.

values.title: Display convergence properties in main GUI to let users know when constraint solvers failed to converge

content.raw: Motivated by issue #1154, typical numerical problems experienced by simulation users.  Providing insights to what's potentially going wrong (or right) with the solver could help debug models and parameters.

values.title: Simplified Animations

content.raw:
The current animations interface seems to require more advanced skeleton features. I would like to be able to supply simple pose/timestamp animations without any of the advanced features via an SDF file like the following:


```
#!xml


        <script>
          <loop>1</loop>
          <delay_start>0.0</delay_start>
          <auto_start>1</auto_start>
          <trajectory>
            <id>0</id>
            <type>translation</type>
            <waypoint><time>0.0   </time><pose>   0  0  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
            <waypoint><time>2.0   </time><pose>  -5 -5  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
            <waypoint><time>4.0   </time><pose>   1  2  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
            <waypoint><time>6.0   </time><pose>  -1 -2  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
            <waypoint><time>8.0   </time><pose>   1 -2  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
            <waypoint><time>10.0  </time><pose>   0  0  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
          </trajectory>
        </script>
```

This is based off of the existing animation code already in gazebo, simply making some existing features optional so it should be fairly easy to implement.
content.html:
The current animations interface seems to require more advanced skeleton features. I would like to be able to supply simple pose/timestamp animations without any of the advanced features via an SDF file like the following:

        <script>
          <loop>1</loop>
          <delay_start>0.0</delay_start>
          <auto_start>1</auto_start>
          <trajectory>
            <id>0</id>
            <type>translation</type>
            <waypoint><time>0.0   </time><pose>   0  0  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
            <waypoint><time>2.0   </time><pose>  -5 -5  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
            <waypoint><time>4.0   </time><pose>   1  2  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
            <waypoint><time>6.0   </time><pose>  -1 -2  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
            <waypoint><time>8.0   </time><pose>   1 -2  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
            <waypoint><time>10.0  </time><pose>   0  0  3  0  0  3.5 </pose></waypoint>
          </trajectory>
        </script>

This is based off of the existing animation code already in gazebo, simply making some existing features optional so it should be fairly easy to implement.

values.title: GpuRaySensor support for intensity readings

content.html:
The GPU ray sensor uses a shader to compute range readings (instead of the collision detection mechanism which is used by the regular CPU ray sensor). This means that the GPU ray sensor does not know what collision shape produced the range reading, and cannot get an intensity reading. the GpuRaySensor::GetRetro functions returens 0.0 

double GpuRaySensor::GetRetro (int /*_index*/) const
{
  return 0.0;
}

Nate Koenig suggested (in his answer to my question in the mailing list) to get the collision shapes using a selection buffer technique.

values.title: Gazebo 3.0 prerelease builds on Ubuntu 14.04 LTS but segfaults on start

content.raw:
Know this is an early / beta issue, but thought it may be good to jot down for record sake, in case somebody else encounters the problem...

I'm running 64bit Ubuntu 14.04 LTS Beta 2. I added the dartcore PPA and installed necessary build dependencies for Gazebo 3.0, including 'sdformat-prerelease_2.0.2' from source, and libbullet2.81 from Gazebo official 'saucy' repository.

http://gazebosim.org/wiki/3.0/install

content.html:
Know this is an early / beta issue, but thought it may be good to jot down for record sake, in case somebody else encounters the problem...

I'm running 64bit Ubuntu 14.04 LTS Beta 2. I added the dartcore PPA and installed necessary build dependencies for Gazebo 3.0, including 'sdformat-prerelease_2.0.2' from source, and libbullet2.81 from Gazebo official 'saucy' repository.

I followed the source build instructions here: http://gazebosim.org/wiki/3.0/install

There were some boost warnings on compilation, because of an incompatibility between the Ubuntu 14.04 default (1.54) and dartcore (1.53).

On running gzserver there is a long pause then segfault.

Here's the verbose output + backtrace:

values.title: gazebo 3.0 ODE screw joint limit error correction term error

content.raw:
We introduced an error when refactoring screw constraint in gazebo_3.0,

[lin_error](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d3c3d1e00d330b6709b476afb28d13b8e44763d0/deps/opende/src/joints/screw.cpp?at=gazebo_3.0#cl-261) was specified in angular form:
~~~
        lin_err = -(lin_disp*thread_pitch-cumulative_angle);
~~~
but it should be in linear displacements
~~~
        lin_err = -(lin_disp-cumulative_angle/thread_pitch);
~~~
content.html:
We introduced an error when refactoring screw constraint in gazebo_3.0,

lin_error was specified in angular form:

        lin_err = -(lin_disp*thread_pitch-cumulative_angle);

but it should be in linear displacements

        lin_err = -(lin_disp-cumulative_angle/thread_pitch);

values.title: Improving Oculus Rift support

content.raw:
Pull request #1074 adds basic Oculus support into Gazebo. The Oculus camera needs to be attached to a visual link. For now, we use a configuration file (gui.ini) to specify the visual link, as well as the initial position of the Oculus window.

It would be nice to open a dialog window when the user press Window->Oculus Rift, that let you select the visual link to attach the Oculus camera, as well as position and orientation offsets.
content.html:
Pull request #1074 adds basic Oculus support into Gazebo. The Oculus camera needs to be attached to a visual link. For now, we use a configuration file (gui.ini) to specify the visual link, as well as the initial position of the Oculus window.

It would be nice to open a dialog window when the user press Window->Oculus Rift, that let you select the visual link to attach the Oculus camera, as well as position and orientation offsets.

values.title: Resetting Gazebo ODE cumulative angle might be broken, tests needed.

content.raw: Currently, resetting simulation through Gazebo's `World::Reset()` call might not do the right thing with ODE's `cumulative_angle` states if wrapping has happened.
content.html: Currently, resetting simulation through Gazebo's World::Reset() call might not do the right thing with ODE's cumulative_angle states if wrapping has happened.

values.title: Support intelligent aligning links in Model Editor

content.raw:
To help users more fluidly/quickly build models, we should support snap-to-grid-like functionality that intelligently aligns links. 

- We can help users create symmetrical models by, for example, symmetrically aligning links to existing identical links when they are dragged nearby.
content.html:
To help users more fluidly/quickly build models, we should support snap-to-grid-like functionality that intelligently aligns links.

  • We can help users create symmetrical models by, for example, symmetrically aligning links to existing identical links when they are dragged nearby.

values.title: Race condition in rendering exposed by pull request #1078

content.raw:
A new test was added to joint_screw.cc in pull request #1078, which caused a race condition seg-fault in rendering.

The race condition causes the `ScrewJointLimitForce/0` (ode) to seg-fault (see [Jenkins test failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-nvidia/8/testReport/junit/%28root%29/INTEGRATION_joint_screw/test_ran/))
when all tests are run sequentially, though it doesn't happen if they are run individually (ie. `test/integration/INTEGRATION_joint_screw --gtest_filter="*ScrewJointLimitForce/0"` doesn't seg-fault).

Here are the console output and backtraces from running the ODE and simbody tests in sequence.

values.title: removing moving model with ode friction fails

content.html:
Hi

I am using gazebo version 2.2.2. I wrote a world plug-in and this plug-in is able to delete models see answers.gazebosim.org but if I have a object moving and an ode friction defined I am getting the following msg and the gazebo server crashes

***** Internal Program Error - assertion (self->inertial != __null)
failed in static void gazebo::physics::ODELink::MoveCallback(dBodyID):
/tmp/buildd/gazebo-current-2.2.2/gazebo/physics/ode/ODELink.cc(183):
Inertial pointer is NULL
Aborted

Removing the object with ModelPtr::Fini() right after it was spawned works but if the objects starts moving I am getting the msg above.

attached you will find an code sample to reproduce the problem.

Greetings

Markus

#include "gazebo/physics/physics.hh"
#include "gazebo/common/common.hh"
#include "gazebo/gazebo.hh"

namespace gazebo
{
class FactoryAndFini : public WorldPlugin
{
    physics::WorldPtr world_;
    boost::shared_ptr<boost::thread> removeThead_;
    boost::shared_ptr<boost::thread> moveThead_;
public:
    void Load(physics::WorldPtr _parent, sdf::ElementPtr /*_sdf*/)
    {
        this->world_ = _parent;
        add("object_static", math::Pose(0,0,0,0,0,0), /*radius*/ 0.3, /*height*/ 2.0, /*mass*/ 10, /*mu*/ 0.0, /*mu2*/ 0.0 );
        std::cout << "added object_static" << std::endl;
        add("object_moving_no_mu", math::Pose(1,0,0,0,0,0), /*radius*/ 0.3, /*height*/ 2.0, /*mass*/ 10, /*mu*/ 0.0, /*mu2*/ 0.0 );
        std::cout << "added object_moving_no_mu" << std::endl;
        add("object_moving_with_mu", math::Pose(2,0,0,0,0,0), /*radius*/ 0.3, /*height*/ 2.0, /*mass*/ 10, /*mu*/ 0.1, /*mu2*/ 0.0 );
        std::cout << "added object_moving_with_mu" << std::endl;


        removeThead_ = boost::shared_ptr<boost::thread>(new boost::thread(&FactoryAndFini::removeTheadFnc, this));
        moveThead_ = boost::shared_ptr<boost::thread>(new boost::thread(&FactoryAndFini::moveTheadFnc, this));
    };

    void moveTheadFnc() {
        sleep(1);
        physics::ModelPtr p;
        p = world_->GetModel("object_moving_no_mu");
        if(p) {
          std::cout << "moving object_moving_no_mu" << std::endl;
          p->SetLinearVel(math::Vector3(0.1, 0, 0));
        }   
        p = world_->GetModel("object_moving_with_mu");
        if(p) {
          std::cout << "moving object_moving_with_mu" << std::endl;
          p->SetLinearVel(math::Vector3(0.1, 0, 0));
        }      
    }
    void removeTheadFnc() {

        sleep(5);
        physics::ModelPtr p;
        std::cout << "removing object_static" << std::endl;
        p =  world_->GetModel("object_static");
        if(p){
          p->Fini(); 
          std::cout << "done removing object_static" << std::endl;
        }
        sleep(1); // This works 
        std::cout << "removing object_moving_no_mu" << std::endl;
        p =  world_->GetModel("object_moving_no_mu");
        if(p){
          p->Fini();  // This works sometimes
          std::cout << "done removing object_moving_no_mu" << std::endl;
        }
        sleep(1);
        std::cout << "removing object_moving_with_mu" << std::endl;
        p =  world_->GetModel("object_moving_with_mu");
        if(p){
          p->Fini();  // This fails allways
          std::cout << "done removing object_moving_with_mu" << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void add(std::string name, const math::Pose &pose, double radius, double length, double mass, double mu, double mu2) {
        std::string modelStr(
            "<sdf version ='1.4'>\
          <model name ='${name}'>\
            <pose>${pose}</pose>\
            <link name ='link'>\
              <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>\
              <collision name ='collision'>\
                <geometry>\
                  <cylinder>\
                    <radius>${radius}</radius>\
                    <length>${length}</length>\
                  </cylinder>\
                </geometry>\
                <surface>\
                  <friction>\
                    <ode>\
                      <mu>${mu}</mu>\
                      <mu2>${mu2}</mu2>\
                    </ode>\
                  </friction>\
                </surface>\
              </collision>\
              <visual name='visual'>\
                <geometry>\
                  <cylinder>\
                    <radius>${radius}</radius>\
                    <length>${length}</length>\
                  </cylinder>\
                </geometry>\
              </visual>\
              <inertial>\
                <mass>${mass}</mass>\
                <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>\
                <inertia>\
                  <ixx>${ixx}</ixx>\
                  <ixy>0.0</ixy>\
                  <ixz>0.0</ixz>\
                  <iyy>${iyy}</iyy>\
                  <iyz>0.0</iyz>\
                  <izz>${izz}</izz>\
                </inertia>\
              </inertial>\
            </link>\
          </model>\
        </sdf>");

        std::stringstream poseStr;
        double ixx = 0.0833333 * mass * (3 * radius * radius + length * length);
        double iyy = 0.0833333 * mass * (3 * radius * radius + length * length);
        double izz = 0.5 * mass * radius * radius;
        poseStr << pose.pos.x << " " << pose.pos.y << " " << pose.pos.z << " 0 0 0";
        boost::replace_all(modelStr, "${name}", name);
        boost::replace_all(modelStr, "${pose}", poseStr.str());
        boost::replace_all(modelStr, "${radius}", boost::lexical_cast<std::string>(radius));
        boost::replace_all(modelStr, "${length}", boost::lexical_cast<std::string>(length));
        boost::replace_all(modelStr, "${mass}", boost::lexical_cast<std::string>(mass));
        boost::replace_all(modelStr, "${ixx}", boost::lexical_cast<std::string>( ixx));
        boost::replace_all(modelStr, "${iyy}", boost::lexical_cast<std::string>( iyy));
        boost::replace_all(modelStr, "${izz}", boost::lexical_cast<std::string>(izz));
        boost::replace_all(modelStr, "${mu}", boost::lexical_cast<std::string>( mu));
        boost::replace_all(modelStr, "${mu2}", boost::lexical_cast<std::string>(mu2));
        sdf::SDF sdfModel;
        sdfModel.SetFromString(modelStr);
        this->world_->InsertModelSDF(sdfModel);
    }
};

// Register this plugin with the simulator
GZ_REGISTER_WORLD_PLUGIN(FactoryAndFini)
}

    <include>

    </include>

    <include>

    <plugin name="factory_and_fini" filename="libfactory_and_fini.so"/>
  </world>
</sdf>

values.title: gazebo and gzserver return without error if gzserver is already running

content.raw:
If a `gzserver` process is already running gazebo and `gzserver` return without error. This is bad in that systems which pass arguments and expect respective action, systems which expect `gzclient` to come up when `gazebo` is run, or systems which expect the call to block until finish do not behave correctly.

Specifically `roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch` does not behave correctly when gzserver is already running.

Optimal behavior is unclear, but a message to stderr seems prudent. 

From the perspective of gzclient expectations:
`gazebo` typically brings up both server and client when there isn't a server running. If a server is already running it seems that it should either bring up the client, or return an error.

From the perspective of plugin loading, it's unclear if the plugins are in-fact loaded if gzserver is already running. If loading does not happen, gazebo should return an error since post conditions aren't meant.
content.html:
If a gzserver process is already running gazebo and gzserver return without error. This is bad in that systems which pass arguments and expect respective action, systems which expect gzclient to come up when gazebo is run, or systems which expect the call to block until finish do not behave correctly.

Specifically roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas.launch does not behave correctly when gzserver is already running.

Optimal behavior is unclear, but a message to stderr seems prudent.

From the perspective of gzclient expectations: gazebo typically brings up both server and client when there isn't a server running. If a server is already running it seems that it should either bring up the client, or return an error.

From the perspective of plugin loading, it's unclear if the plugins are in-fact loaded if gzserver is already running. If loading does not happen, gazebo should return an error since post conditions aren't meant.

values.title: Exceptions no longer print file:line from where they were thrown

content.raw:
Prior to pull request #894, a `gzthrow` would print the file and line number in a console message, for example:
~~~
79: Exception [ODEJoint.cc:231] ODEHinge2Joint cannot be connected to the world
~~~
The switch to using `gzerr` in `Exception::Print()` means that `Exception.cc:52` is printed with every exception, which is not useful.
~~~
[Err] [Exception.cc:52] EXCEPTION: Unable to start server[bind: Address already in use]. There is probably another Gazebo process running.
~~~
We should use `std::cerr` instead of `gzerr` or figure out a way to use the correct file and line number.
content.html:
Prior to pull request #894, a gzthrow would print the file and line number in a console message, for example:

79: Exception [ODEJoint.cc:231] ODEHinge2Joint cannot be connected to the world

The switch to using gzerr in Exception::Print() means that Exception.cc:52 is printed with every exception, which is not useful.

[Err] [Exception.cc:52] EXCEPTION: Unable to start server[bind: Address already in use]. There is probably another Gazebo process running.

We should use std::cerr instead of gzerr or figure out a way to use the correct file and line number.

values.title: Seg-fault during Material destructor

As mentioned in [release-tools #20](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/issue/20/jenkins-misses-some-testing-seg-faults), there are some tests that seg-fault so late that Jenkins thinks that they passed. Specifically, the INTEGRATION_concave_mesh test has been seg-faulting since pull request #1066. Through testing, I have identified the tests involving submeshes (ie. `--gtest_filter="*SubmeshCollisionTest*"` or `--gtest_filter="*SubmeshNoCollisionTest*"`).

Note that it is [not listed in the list of failing tests](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-nvidia/717/testReport/), but it is shown as seg-faulting in the
[console output](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-nvidia/717/consoleFull):

values.title: Create a test to check that the result of two gzserver instances

content.raw:
Motivation comes from pull request #1085.

We should find a way of launching (and be able to terminate) two instances of gzserver (or gzserver + gazebo) and check for the result of both. Integrate this into google test using fork commands is probably not an option. Another option would be to use system calls and background, but need more time before thinking in such a dirty thing.

values.title: Deleting light only deletes it in client, not on server

content.raw:
To reproduce, load gazebo with an empty world:
~~~
$ gazebo
~~~
Expand the lights on the left widget, right click on sun and click `Delete`. The ground plane should darken. Then open a separate gzclient in another terminal, the ground plane will be lit, and the sun will be present in the list of lights.
content.html:
To reproduce, load gazebo with an empty world:

$ gazebo

Expand the lights on the left widget, right click on sun and click Delete. The ground plane should darken. Then open a separate gzclient in another terminal, the ground plane will be lit, and the sun will be present in the list of lights.

values.title: Camera Plugin: Model is not shown if it has been previously deleted and then re-spawned

content.raw:
In Gazebo 2.2.2, I've found an issue with the camera plugin where a model with a given name will not be rendered in the camera view if it had previously been deleted.

**Repro**

- spawn a model X with name Y with a camera attached to it, looking at itself
- verify that the model can be seen in the camera view
- delete the model
- spawn the same model X with the same name Y

expected: the model should again be seen in the camera view
actual: the model is not seen in the camera view

  • delete the model
  • spawn the same model X with the same name Y

expected: the model should again be seen in the camera view actual: the model is not seen in the camera view

values.title: gzsdf: Can't disable gravity for a single link

content.raw:
When using gzsdf to convert an URDF with a `<gazebo>` tag with a `<gravity>` child like the following, gzsdf adds an additional `<gravity>` tag which re-enables it. This prevents the feature from being used via URDF.

in URDF:

```
<gazebo reference="link_name">
  <gravity>0</gravity>
</gazebo>
```

in generated SDF:

```
<link name="link_name">
  <!-- ... -->
  <gravity>0</gravity>
  <gravity>1</gravity>
</link>
```

When trying to spawn a similar URDF in gazebo, errors similar to these are shown:
```
Warning [parser_urdf.cc:1010] multiple inconsistent <gravity> exists due to fixed joint reduction overwriting previous value [false] with [true].
Warning [parser_urdf.cc:1010] multiple inconsistent <gravity> exists due to fixed joint reduction overwriting previous value [false] with [true].
Warning [parser_urdf.cc:1010] multiple inconsistent <gravity> exists due to fixed joint reduction overwriting previous value [0] with [true].
```

values.title: Can't get animate_joints plugin working

content.raw:
Hi There

I'm modelling a quadrotor in gazebo, and I would like some nice spinning blades for visual effect. However, I don't want the blades to have any physical effect on the dynamics of the platform.

My idea is to have a gravity effected body with mass connected by revolute joints to massless, static blades. I then used a simple NumericAnimation to animate the joints. I got this working in gazebo 2, but it stopped working in gazebo3.

Is there a known issue with NumericAnimation that prevents this from working. I tried to update the animate_joint.world example (see below) with no luck. Is there a new trick to animating a revolute joint between dynamic and static models?

Cheers
Andrew

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="test">
   
    <!-- Physics -->
    <physics type="ode">
      <max_step_size>0.02</max_step_size>
      <real_time_factor>1.0</real_time_factor>
      <real_time_update_rate>50</real_time_update_rate>
    </physics>

    <!-- Setup a basic scene with a sky and clouds -->
    <scene>
      <sky>
        <time>12.00</time>
        <sunrise>06.23</sunrise>
        <sunset>17.59</sunset>
        <clouds>
          <speed>12</speed>
        </clouds>
      </sky>
      <shadows>false</shadows>
    </scene>

    <!-- Sun -->
    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>

    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>

    <model name="box">

      <static>true</static>

      <link name="base_link">

        <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>

        <inertial>
          <mass>1</mass>
        </inertial>

        <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>

        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </visual>

      </link>

      <link name="top_link">

        <pose>0 0 1.3 0 0 0</pose>

        <inertial>
          <mass>1</mass>
        </inertial>

        <collision name="collision">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>.5 .5 .5</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>
        
        <visual name="visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>.5 .5 .5</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      
      </link>

      <joint name="my_joint" type="prismatic">
        <parent>base_link</parent>
        <child>top_link</child>
        <axis>
          <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>

      <plugin name="animate_joints" filename="libanimate_joints.so"/>

    </model>

  </world>
</sdf>
```

values.title: libogre-1.8-dev dependency conflict

When using ROS Indgo, gazebo2 requires libogre-1.8-dev but MoveIt and other ROS packages require libogre-1.9-dev. It appears both of these ogre deps cannot be installed together. I get the error:

```
  apt: command [sudo apt-get install -y gazebo2] failed

```
I'm not sure how to resolve this conflict. I'm on Ubuntu 14.04

May be related to #!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1183/dependency-issues-when-installing-from

values.title: Simulating Thermal Cameras

content.raw:
Every now and then, requests for simulating different spectra than the default visible light pop up, notably thermal imaging. I implemented a quick hack for simulating thermal cameras as described [here on ROS Answers](http://answers.ros.org/question/28028/simulating-a-thermal-camera-in-gazebo/) and available in [hector_gazebo_thermal_camera](http://wiki.ros.org/hector_gazebo_thermal_camera), but that clearly only works for some scenarios. This ticket is for discussion and tracking any effort towards simulating thermal cameras. I do not have the time to work on this, but maybe someone else steps in.

Issue #550 about arbitrary model properties is related to this one as implementing those could be a proper path towards thermal imaging simulation.
content.html:
Every now and then, requests for simulating different spectra than the default visible light pop up, notably thermal imaging. I implemented a quick hack for simulating thermal cameras as described here on ROS Answers and available in hector_gazebo_thermal_camera, but that clearly only works for some scenarios. This ticket is for discussion and tracking any effort towards simulating thermal cameras. I do not have the time to work on this, but maybe someone else steps in.

Issue #550 about arbitrary model properties is related to this one as implementing those could be a proper path towards thermal imaging simulation.

values.title: World::GetRealTime does not advance when simulation is paused, and World::Step() is called one step at a time.

content.html:
example test that leads to failure against gazebo_3.0 branch:

$ hg diff test/integration/physics.cc 
diff -r 950f53df81f9 test/integration/physics.cc
--- a/test/integration/physics.cc   Tue May 20 15:20:15 2014 -0700
+++ b/test/integration/physics.cc   Tue May 20 18:05:57 2014 -0700
@@ -71,6 +71,15 @@
   EXPECT_GT(dt, 0);
   t = world->GetSimTime().Double();
   EXPECT_GT(t, 0.99*dt*static_cast<double>(steps+1));
+
+  // test World::GetRealTime()
+  world->SetPaused(true);
+  double startRealTime = world->GetRealTime().Double();
+  for(unsigned int i = 0; i < 2000; ++i)
+  {
+    world->Step(1);
+    EXPECT_GT(world->GetRealTime().Double(), startRealTime);
+  }
 }

 TEST_P(PhysicsTest, EmptyWorld)

Documentation on what World::GetRealTime() should do does not specify if this is the expected behavior.

values.title: Tip for installing Gazebo3 on OS X 10.9

content.raw:
Sorry I couldn't find good place to put this information.

Recently I finished install Gazebo3 on Max OS X 10.9.

"Before trying to install you should check your x11 version".
Don't follow my method before reading this article please.

When you try to install Gazebo3, that script will attempt to build all of dependancies. (freetype, ogre, qt, ....). Than you may have an error message that all of dependent package are not installed. Perhaps you will have not ogre package.

But there is a method to build ogre.
see an answer --> http://answers.ros.org/question/162956/fails-to-build-ogre-on-os-x-1092/

That answer described to suggest deleting some header file of freetype package from x11. Than re-try to build ogre using a commend "brew install -v ogre --HEAD".
It can be done just for installing ogre (1.9), but Gazebo don't allow using last version ogre. Because when you are using that version, you may have run time error. So this is bad choice to install Gazebo. 
You may notice that problem is mainly caused from XQuartz.

Therefore the Idea is this changing XQuartz version. 
In that time I had last version of XQuartz (2.7.6) since I followed install instruction on website.
see ->> http://gazebosim.org/wiki/3.0/install#Compiling_From_Source_.28Mac_OS_X.29

I uninstalled 'home-brew' and removed all caches (/Library/Caches) that I downloaded package for install Gazebo. Also I uninstalled XQuartz. After removing all these things I installed home-brew and **'XQuartz 2.7.2'** again.

Now you can follow next step.
$brew tap osrf/simulation
$brew install gazebo3
$gazebo

Finally you will have Gazebo window!

I hope this article will help someone who want to install Gazebo on OS X.
content.html:
Sorry I couldn't find good place to put this information.

Recently I finished install Gazebo3 on Max OS X 10.9.

"Before trying to install you should check your x11 version". Don't follow my method before reading this article please.

When you try to install Gazebo3, that script will attempt to build all of dependancies. (freetype, ogre, qt, ....). Than you may have an error message that all of dependent package are not installed. Perhaps you will have not ogre package.

But there is a method to build ogre. see an answer --> http://answers.ros.org/question/162956/fails-to-build-ogre-on-os-x-1092/

That answer described to suggest deleting some header file of freetype package from x11. Than re-try to build ogre using a commend "brew install -v ogre --HEAD". It can be done just for installing ogre (1.9), but Gazebo don't allow using last version ogre. Because when you are using that version, you may have run time error. So this is bad choice to install Gazebo. You may notice that problem is mainly caused from XQuartz.

Therefore the Idea is this changing XQuartz version. In that time I had last version of XQuartz (2.7.6) since I followed install instruction on website. see ->> http://gazebosim.org/wiki/3.0/install#Compiling_From_Source_.28Mac_OS_X.29

I uninstalled 'home-brew' and removed all caches (/Library/Caches) that I downloaded package for install Gazebo. Also I uninstalled XQuartz. After removing all these things I installed home-brew and 'XQuartz 2.7.2' again.

Now you can follow next step. $brew tap osrf/simulation $brew install gazebo3 $gazebo

Finally you will have Gazebo window!

I hope this article will help someone who want to install Gazebo on OS X.

values.title: Race condition when using BulletJoint::GetForceTorque

content.raw:
There seems to be a race condition in `BulletJoint::GetForceTorque` that causes it to pass or fail test `REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame` randomly. 

To replicate this bug, enable test REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame for Bullet 
by removing the hardcoded if in `940_force_torque_sensor_frame.cc` file

Additional information can be found in [issue 940](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/940/force-torque-sensor-forcetorquesensorcc) discussion.
content.html:
There seems to be a race condition in BulletJoint::GetForceTorque that causes it to pass or fail test REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame randomly.

To replicate this bug, enable test REGRESSION_940_force_torque_sensor_frame for Bullet by removing the hardcoded if in 940_force_torque_sensor_frame.cc file

Additional information can be found in issue 940 discussion.

values.title: Model::GetJoint deprecation warnings

content.raw:
Allowing `Model::GetJoint` to accept un-scoped joint names was deprecated in pull request #1067 with a console warning message (it's a run-time thing behavior not a build-time thing). It gives the following message:
~~~
[Wrn] [Model.cc:569] Calling Model::GetJoint(lower_joint) with un-scoped joint name is deprecated, please scope
~~~
Searching through our Jenkins logs shows many instances of this in our test suite. [For example](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-precise-amd64-gpu-nvidia/733/consoleFull), the following tests have this error:
~~~
103: [ RUN      ] PhysicsEngines/ForceTorqueSensor_TEST.ForceTorqueTest/0
143: [ RUN      ] PhysicsEngines/JointLiftDragPluginTest.LiftDragPlugin1/0
157: [ RUN      ] GripperTest.Close
...
~~~

157: [ RUN      ] GripperTest.Close
...

values.title: Cache results of Joint::FindAllConnectedLinks and warn only once per model change

content.raw:
Cache results of [Joint::FindAllConnectedLinks()](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/d7664a8b6e7e9cb597eb3708088b367874273274/gazebo/physics/Joint.cc?at=set_joint_position_gazebo_4.0#cl-1122) and warn on setting looped-joints only once per model change even if `SetPosition` is called repeatedly.

Doing so should reduce spam and help `Joint::SetPosition` performance.

Breaks ABI, need to merge before Gazebo 4.0 release unless PIMPL-ized first.
content.html:
Cache results of Joint::FindAllConnectedLinks() and warn on setting looped-joints only once per model change even if SetPosition is called repeatedly.

Doing so should reduce spam and help Joint::SetPosition performance.

Breaks ABI, need to merge before Gazebo 4.0 release unless PIMPL-ized first.
